<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- Calculators must not be used in this paper.- You must show all necessary working clearly.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 568, 88]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 104, 783, 123]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 153, 673, 171]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 201, 685, 219]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 244, 680, 272]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 293, 685, 320]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 346, 655, 364]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 365, 560, 400]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 444, 225, 460]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 435, 905, 476]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 482, 770, 524]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 555, 220, 570]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 552, 668, 594]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 630, 220, 645]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 628, 572, 710]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 739, 158, 754]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 737, 555, 788]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^2 A + \cos^2 A = 1 \\ \sec^2 A = 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cosec^2 A = 1 + \cot^2 A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 828, 240, 844]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 822, 576, 900]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 72, 665, 89]]<|/det|>
<pre>Calculators must **not** be used in this paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 112, 94, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 110, 144, 129]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 588, 134]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\overrightarrow{PQ} = \binom{- 3}{7}\) and \(4\overrightarrow{PR} = \binom{- 2}{8}\) , find \(\overrightarrow{RQ}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 110, 920, 129]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 422, 146, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 422, 918, 456]]<|/det|>
The vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) , \(\mathbf{b}\) and \(\mathbf{c}\) are such that \(\mathbf{a} = \alpha \mathbf{i} + 6\mathbf{j}\) , \(\mathbf{b} = 4\mathbf{i} + \beta \mathbf{j}\) and \(\mathbf{c} = (2\alpha +5\beta)\mathbf{i} + 20\mathbf{j}\) , where \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are scalars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 562, 485]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathbf{c} = 3\mathbf{a} - 2\mathbf{b}\) , find the values of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 467, 920, 485]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 368, 90]]<|/det|>
Point \(A\) has coordinates \((3, - 1)\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 98, 470, 119]]<|/det|>
A circle has equation \(\left(x - 4\right)^{2} + \left(y + 3\right)^{2} = 5.\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 138, 146, 155]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 138, 556, 155]]<|/det|>
Show that \(A\) lies on the circumference of the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 138, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 262, 148, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 262, 677, 280]]<|/det|>
Given that \(AB\) is a diameter of the circle, find the coordinates of \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 262, 920, 280]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 618, 146, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 618, 544, 636]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the tangent to the circle at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 618, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 149, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 75, 463, 94]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\quad 5|2x - 1| + 8 = 23.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 918, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 275, 146, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 275, 700, 294]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graph of \(\quad y = 5\sin x - 2\) for \(0^{\circ}\leqslant x\leqslant 360^{\circ}.\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 275, 918, 294]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 325, 789, 585]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 88, 94, 107]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 420, 115]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \left(\frac{x^2 - 1}{x^2 + 1}\right)^4\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 127, 146, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 850, 166]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\) can be written as \(\frac{Ax\left(x^{2} - 1\right)^{3}}{\left(x^{2} + 1\right)^{5}}\) , where \(A\) is a positive integer to be found. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 180, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 764, 92]]<|/det|>
Show that the curve has stationary points where \(x = -1\) , \(x = 0\) and \(x = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 197, 180, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 197, 918, 230]]<|/det|>
Use the first derivative test to determine which two stationary points have the same nature and state whether they are maximum or minimum points.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 211, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 677, 90]]<|/det|>
Solutions to this question by accurate drawing will not be accepted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 95, 865, 113]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinates of the points where the curve \(y = (2x - 9)\big(x^{2} + 5\big) + 42\) cuts the \(x\)-axis. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 149, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 75, 678, 92]]<|/det|>
Write down the set of values of \(x\) for which \(\log_5(12x - 4)\) exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 165, 149, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 164, 546, 190]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 450, 616, 467]]<|/det|>
The point \(A\) with \(x\)-coordinate 2 lies on the curve \(\quad y = \sqrt{4x + 1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 466, 670, 482]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of this curve and the tangent to the curve at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 496, 770, 513]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region enclosed by the curve, the tangent and the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 496, 920, 513]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 465, 88]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 81, 106, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 144, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 848, 108]]<|/det|>
Given that \(0 \leqslant \theta < \frac{\pi}{2}\) , show that \(\frac{\sin \theta}{\sqrt{\cos \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{x}} \theta - 1}} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + \tan^2 \theta}}\) can be written as \(\sec \theta\). [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 81, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 500, 148, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 492, 709, 520]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\sec x = \alpha\) , where \(\frac{3\pi}{2} < x \leqslant 2\pi\) , find \(\sin x\) in terms of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 497, 920, 517]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 102, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 529, 88]]<|/det|>
An arithmetic progression has common difference \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 88, 418, 104]]<|/det|>
The 3rd term of this progression is 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 146, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 119, 758, 135]]<|/det|>
Write down expressions for the 1st term and the 2nd term of this progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 450, 151]]<|/det|>
Give your answers in terms of \(d\) only.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 135, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 146, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 289, 735, 305]]<|/det|>
When each of the first 3 terms is squared, the sum of these squares is 140 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 305, 437, 320]]<|/det|>
There are two possible values for \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 918, 368]]<|/det|>
Using your answer to part **(a)**, find the sum of the first 200 terms of the progression with the smaller value of \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 104, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 301, 90]]<|/det|>
In this question \(n \geqslant 6\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 87, 730, 106]]<|/det|>
Use an algebraic method to show that \({}^n\mathrm{C}_5 - {}^n\mathrm{-}1\mathrm{C}_5\) can be written as \({}^n\mathrm{-}1\mathrm{C}_4\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
